steps.title: Find other players.
steps.content: Find other players. Round up two or more people. Each person is their own team. Everyone keeps track of their own score. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Designate the free-throw line.
steps.content: Designate the free-throw line. On a regulation basketball court, this is a straight horizontal line. Usually, this is 15 feet (4.6 m) from the basket. [2] X Research source However, if you’re playing on a driveway or smaller court, you can improvise.

steps.title: Designate the 3-point line.
steps.content: Designate the 3-point line. This is the large semi-circle that encloses the free-throw line on a regulation court. Usually, this is 23.75 feet (7.24 m) from the basket. [3] X Research source Feel free to improvise on a smaller court.

steps.title: Establish the rules.
steps.content: Establish the rules. Every game of 21 has its basic rules. However, you and the other players can make adjustments to create a challenge or make things easier for beginners. [4] X Research source Some common rules are: Regular shots are worth 2 points each. You can make them anywhere on the court except the free-throw or 3-point line. 3-point shots are worth 3 points each. Make them from the 3-point line. Free-throw shots are worth 1 point each. Make them from the free-throw line. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Determine who takes the first shot.
steps.content: Determine who takes the first shot. Take turns shooting at the hoop rim. The first person to hit the rim takes possession of the ball. You could adjust this rule so that you have to get the ball in the basket in order to take possession.

steps.title: Start the game.
steps.content: Start the game. The player with possession shoots the ball at the 3-point line. All other players try to stop them from making the basket. [6] X Research source This is called busting-in or breaking-in the ball. A successful bust gets the opponent 2 points. [7] X Research source

steps.title: Get extra shots.
steps.content: Get extra shots. Each 2-point shot you make earns you a 1-point shot from the free-throw line. After you make 3 shots in a row, one of your opponents can check you in a one-on-one match-up. If you make that shot, you get 2 points. If you miss your free throw, try to stop your opponents from putting the ball back in the basket.

steps.title: Clear the ball.
steps.content: Clear the ball. Dribble the ball outside the 3-point line. This happens if someone misses the 2-point shot and one of their opponents rebounds the ball. The player with the ball can’t shoot before clearing. [8] X Research source

steps.title: Continue the game.
steps.content: Continue the game. Shoot additional 1- 2-, and 3-point shots until someone gets 21 points. In basic rules, the first player to 21 wins. You could end the game there or have a rematch.

steps.title: Penalize tip-ins.
steps.content: Penalize tip-ins. In a tip-in, one player shoots the ball toward the basket but misses. Meanwhile, another player jumps, catches the ball, and scores before it hits the ground. [9] X Research source Make the game more challenging by reducing the score of the “tipped” shooter (the one who missed their shot). You can reduce it to 13 or a lower number if the player has less than 13 points. To make it even more interesting, reduce the score to zero.

steps.title: Don’t stop at 21 points.
steps.content: Don’t stop at 21 points. Make a rule that the winner must have at least 21 points and lead by a set number of points. For example, you could agree to continue beyond 21 points until someone leads by 2, 4, or more points.

steps.title: Penalize a missed free-throw.
steps.content: Penalize a missed free-throw. Sometimes, a player will have to make a free-throw shot in order to make it to 21. If they miss, their score gets rolled back to 13 points.
